snippet: A playoff hero and a World Series goat, Murphy is likely, but not certain, to make more if he rejects the one-year deal and becomes a free agent.
abstract: David Waldstein On Baseball column examines decision by New York Mets to extend one-year, $15.8 million qualifying offer to second baseman Daniel Murphy; notes Murphy has one week to accept or reject it; observes move was smart as it allows Mets to receive draft pick as compensation if Murphy signs elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: A playoff hero and a World Series goat, Murphy is likely, but not certain, to make more if he rejects the one-year deal and becomes a free agent.

headline.print_headline: Mets Gamble $15.8 Million in Offer to Murphy
headline.main: Mets Gamble With $15.8 Million Offer to Daniel Murphy, Who Faces a Bigger Gamble
